laws.summary: Wisconsin does not have a statewide law prohibiting employers from asking applicants about salary history.
requirements: Employers may legally ask about prior salary
Use of salary history may increase risk under federal anti-discrimination laws
Best practice is to avoid salary history inquiries
laws.notes: Although permitted, many employers avoid salary history questions to reduce Equal Pay Act and Title VII risk.

laws.summary: Wisconsin does not require employers to disclose wage ranges in job postings or offer letters.
laws.statute_citation: No current Wisconsin statute mandating pay transparency
requirements: Wage range disclosure is not legally required
Employers may voluntarily disclose compensation information
Federal equal pay and anti-discrimination laws still apply
laws.notes: Some employers voluntarily disclose pay ranges for consistency with other states.

laws.summary: Non-compete agreements are enforceable in Wisconsin only if they are reasonable and narrowly tailored under strict statutory standards.
requirements: Must be reasonably necessary to protect employer's legitimate business interests
Must be reasonable in duration
Must be reasonable in geographic scope
Must not be harsh, oppressive, or unconscionable
Overly broad non-competes are void in their entirety (courts do not rewrite them)
laws.notes: Wisconsin is one of the strictest states on non-competes. Overbroad clauses are completely unenforceable.

laws.summary: Wisconsin does not have a statewide ban-the-box law for private employers, but federal FCRA requirements apply when using third-party background check vendors.
requirements: Written consent required before third-party background checks
Must provide pre-adverse action notice before taking negative action
Must provide copy of report and summary of rights
Must issue adverse action notice if decision is finalized
Criminal history use must be non-discriminatory
laws.notes: Applies whenever a consumer reporting agency is used.

laws.summary: Wisconsin does not mandate paid sick leave statewide but protects certain civic and statutory leave rights.
laws.statute_citation: Wis. Stat. § 756.255 (jury duty); § 6.76 (voting leave); § 103.10 (Wisconsin Family and Medical Leave Act)
requirements: Employers must allow employees to attend jury duty without retaliation
Employees must be allowed up to 3 consecutive hours off to vote if schedule conflicts with polling hours
Wisconsin FMLA provides job-protected unpaid leave to eligible employees
No statewide paid sick leave mandate
laws.notes: Offer letters should not conflict with statutory civic leave or WI FMLA rights.

laws.summary: Wisconsin permits workplace drug testing and does not provide employment protections for recreational cannabis use.
laws.statute_citation: Wisconsin Statutes Title 111; criminal statutes governing marijuana
requirements: Employers may maintain drug-free workplace policies
Employers may discipline or refuse to hire based on positive drug tests
Cannabis remains illegal for recreational use in Wisconsin
Drug testing policies should be applied consistently
laws.notes: Wisconsin is employer-friendly regarding drug testing policies.

laws.summary: Arbitration agreements are generally enforceable in Wisconsin if consistent with contract law and federal arbitration principles.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act; Wisconsin Uniform Arbitration Act (Wis. Stat. § 788.01 et seq.)
requirements: Agreement must be clear and voluntary
Must not be unconscionable
Must provide reasonable notice
Courts may invalidate overly one-sided clauses
laws.notes: Fairness and clarity are key for enforceability.

laws.summary: Wisconsin follows the at-will employment doctrine, subject to statutory, contractual, and public policy exceptions.
requirements: Employment is presumed at-will unless contract provides otherwise
Cannot terminate for discriminatory reasons
Cannot retaliate for protected activity
Public policy exceptions apply
Employee handbooks may create implied contractual obligations
laws.notes: Clear at-will language in offer letters is recommended.

laws.summary: Wisconsin law prohibits discrimination in employment based on protected characteristics.
laws.statute_citation: Wisconsin Fair Employment Act (Wis. Stat. § 111.31 et seq.)
requirements: Cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin
Cannot discriminate based on disability
Cannot discriminate based on age (40+)
Cannot discriminate based on sexual orientation
Harassment is prohibited
Retaliation for protected activity is prohibited
laws.notes: Wisconsin explicitly protects sexual orientation under state law.

data_quality.sources: Wisconsin Department of Workforce Development, Wisconsin Statutes, official state agency guidance
data_quality.coverage_completeness: comprehensive for offer-letter and hiring compliance

additional_notes.general_guidance: Wisconsin is employer-friendly in many areas but very strict on non-compete drafting; overbroad clauses are void entirely.
recent_developments: No statewide pay transparency law enacted as of 2026
No statewide paid sick leave mandate
Continued strict enforcement of non-compete statute
